<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><Highlight kind="comment">/// GlobalNumberState assigns an integer to each global value in the program,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><Highlight kind="comment">/// which is used by the comparison routine to order references to globals. This</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><Highlight kind="comment">/// state must be preserved throughout the pass, because Functions and other</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><Highlight kind="comment">/// globals need to maintain their relative order. Globals are assigned a number</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><Highlight kind="comment">/// when they are first visited. This order is deterministic, and so the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><Highlight kind="comment">/// assigned numbers are as well. When two functions are merged, neither number</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><Highlight kind="comment">/// is updated. If the symbols are weak, this would be incorrect. If they are</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><Highlight kind="comment">/// strong, then one will be replaced at all references to the other, and so</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><Highlight kind="comment">/// direct callsites will now see one or the other symbol, and no update is</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><Highlight kind="comment">/// necessary. Note that if we were guaranteed unique names, we could just</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><Highlight kind="comment">/// compare those, but this would not work for stripped bitcodes or for those</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"><Highlight kind="comment">/// few symbols without a name.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="54" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalnumberstate"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">class </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalnumberstate/#a0a7bcd4ca9779d35aad65231c24fc5b4">GlobalNumberState</a> &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">struct </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">Config : <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/valuemapconfig">ValueMapConfig</a>&lt;GlobalValue &#42;&gt; &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">enum</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> &#123; <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/valuemapconfig/#a1b685c420b60f4e957db67c7a6c87d5da802434572dcd90e300fb465562d4f41b">FollowRAUW</a> = </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">false</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> &#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><Highlight kind="normal">  &#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Each GlobalValue is mapped to an identifier. The Config ensures when RAUW</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// occurs, the mapping does not change. Tracking changes is unnecessary, and</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// also problematic for weak symbols (which may be overwritten).</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00112" /><CodeLine lineNumber="112"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Test whether two basic blocks have equivalent behaviour.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00113" /><CodeLine lineNumber="113"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#a21408b47716ef75ac95ded9097918f0a">cmpBasicBlocks</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42;BBL, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42;BBR) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Constants comparison.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Its analog to lexicographical comparison between hypothetical numbers</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00117" /><CodeLine lineNumber="117"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// of next format:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00118" /><CodeLine lineNumber="118"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &lt;bitcastability-trait&gt;&lt;raw-bit-contents&gt;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00119" /><CodeLine lineNumber="119"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 Bitcastability.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Check whether L&#39;s type could be losslessly bitcasted to R&#39;s type.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// On this stage method, in case when lossless bitcast is not possible</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// method returns -1 or 1, thus also defining which type is greater in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// context of bitcastability.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 0: If types are equal in terms of cmpTypes, then we can go straight</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          to the contents comparison.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          If types differ, remember types comparison result and check</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          whether we still can bitcast types.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 1: Types that satisfies isFirstClassType conditions are always</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          greater then others.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 2: Vector is greater then non-vector.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          If both types are vectors, then vector with greater bitwidth is</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          greater.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          If both types are vectors with the same bitwidth, then types</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          are bitcastable, and we can skip other stages, and go to contents</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          comparison.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 3: Pointer types are greater than non-pointers. If both types are</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          pointers of the same address space - go to contents comparison.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          Different address spaces: pointer with greater address space is</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          greater.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 4: Types are neither vectors, nor pointers. And they differ.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          We don&#39;t know how to bitcast them. So, we better don&#39;t do it,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          and return types comparison result (so it determines the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          relationship among constants we don&#39;t know how to bitcast).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Just for clearance, let&#39;s see how the set of constants could look</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// on single dimension axis:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00149" /><CodeLine lineNumber="149"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#91;NFCT&#93;, &#91;FCT, &quot;others&quot;&#93;, &#91;FCT, pointers&#93;, &#91;FCT, vectors&#93;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00150" /><CodeLine lineNumber="150"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Where: NFCT - Not a FirstClassType</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00151" /><CodeLine lineNumber="151"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///        FCT - FirstClassTyp:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00152" /><CodeLine lineNumber="152"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00153" /><CodeLine lineNumber="153"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 Compare raw contents.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00154" /><CodeLine lineNumber="154"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// It ignores types on this stage and only compares bits from L and R.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00155" /><CodeLine lineNumber="155"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Returns 0, if L and R has equivalent contents.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00156" /><CodeLine lineNumber="156"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// -1 or 1 if values are different.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00157" /><CodeLine lineNumber="157"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Pretty trivial:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00158" /><CodeLine lineNumber="158"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2.1. If contents are numbers, compare numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00159" /><CodeLine lineNumber="159"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    Ints with greater bitwidth are greater. Ints with same bitwidths</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00160" /><CodeLine lineNumber="160"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    compared by their contents.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00161" /><CodeLine lineNumber="161"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2.2. &quot;And so on&quot;. Just to avoid discrepancies with comments</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00162" /><CodeLine lineNumber="162"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// perhaps it would be better to read the implementation itself.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00163" /><CodeLine lineNumber="163"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 3 And again about overall picture. Let&#39;s look back at how the ordered set</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00164" /><CodeLine lineNumber="164"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// of constants will look like:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00165" /><CodeLine lineNumber="165"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#91;NFCT&#93;, &#91;FCT, &quot;others&quot;&#93;, &#91;FCT, pointers&#93;, &#91;FCT, vectors&#93;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00166" /><CodeLine lineNumber="166"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00167" /><CodeLine lineNumber="167"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Now look, what could be inside &#91;FCT, &quot;others&quot;&#93;, for example:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00168" /><CodeLine lineNumber="168"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#91;FCT, &quot;others&quot;&#93; =</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00169" /><CodeLine lineNumber="169"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#91;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00170" /><CodeLine lineNumber="170"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#91;double 0.1&#93;, &#91;double 1.23&#93;,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00171" /><CodeLine lineNumber="171"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#91;i32 1&#93;, &#91;i32 2&#93;,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00172" /><CodeLine lineNumber="172"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#123; double 1 &#125;,       ; StructTyID, NumElements = 1</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00173" /><CodeLine lineNumber="173"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#123; i32 1 &#125;,            ; StructTyID, NumElements = 1</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00174" /><CodeLine lineNumber="174"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#123; double 1, i32 1 &#125;,  ; StructTyID, NumElements = 2</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00175" /><CodeLine lineNumber="175"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///   &#123; i32 1, double 1 &#125;   ; StructTyID, NumElements = 2</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00176" /><CodeLine lineNumber="176"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#93;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00177" /><CodeLine lineNumber="177"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00178" /><CodeLine lineNumber="178"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Let&#39;s explain the order. Float numbers will be less than integers, just</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00179" /><CodeLine lineNumber="179"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// because of cmpType terms: FloatTyID &lt; IntegerTyID.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00180" /><CodeLine lineNumber="180"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Floats (with same fltSemantics) are sorted according to their value.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00181" /><CodeLine lineNumber="181"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Then you can see integers, and they are, like a floats,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00182" /><CodeLine lineNumber="182"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// could be easy sorted among each others.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00183" /><CodeLine lineNumber="183"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// The structures. Structures are grouped at the tail, again because of their</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00184" /><CodeLine lineNumber="184"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// TypeID: StructTyID &gt; IntegerTyID &gt; FloatTyID.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00185" /><CodeLine lineNumber="185"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Structures with greater number of elements are greater. Structures with</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00186" /><CodeLine lineNumber="186"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// greater elements going first are greater.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00187" /><CodeLine lineNumber="187"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// The same logic with vectors, arrays and other possible complex types.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00188" /><CodeLine lineNumber="188"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00189" /><CodeLine lineNumber="189"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Bitcastable constants.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00190" /><CodeLine lineNumber="190"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Let&#39;s assume, that some constant, belongs to some group of</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00191" /><CodeLine lineNumber="191"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &quot;so-called-equal&quot; values with different types, and at the same time</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00192" /><CodeLine lineNumber="192"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// belongs to another group of constants with equal types</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00193" /><CodeLine lineNumber="193"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// and &quot;really&quot; equal values.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00194" /><CodeLine lineNumber="194"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00195" /><CodeLine lineNumber="195"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Now, prove that this is impossible:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00196" /><CodeLine lineNumber="196"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00197" /><CodeLine lineNumber="197"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If constant A with type TyA is bitcastable to B with type TyB, then:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00198" /><CodeLine lineNumber="198"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 All constants with equal types to TyA, are bitcastable to B. Since</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00199" /><CodeLine lineNumber="199"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    those should be vectors (if TyA is vector), pointers</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00200" /><CodeLine lineNumber="200"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    (if TyA is pointer), or else (if TyA equal to TyB), those types should</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00201" /><CodeLine lineNumber="201"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    be equal to TyB.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00202" /><CodeLine lineNumber="202"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 All constants with non-equal, but bitcastable types to TyA, are</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00203" /><CodeLine lineNumber="203"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    bitcastable to B.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00204" /><CodeLine lineNumber="204"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    Once again, just because we allow it to vectors and pointers only.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00205" /><CodeLine lineNumber="205"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    This statement could be expanded as below:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00206" /><CodeLine lineNumber="206"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2.1. All vectors with equal bitwidth to vector A, has equal bitwidth to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00207" /><CodeLine lineNumber="207"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///      vector B, and thus bitcastable to B as well.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00208" /><CodeLine lineNumber="208"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2.2. All pointers of the same address space, no matter what they point to,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00209" /><CodeLine lineNumber="209"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///      bitcastable. So if C is pointer, it could be bitcasted to A and to B.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00210" /><CodeLine lineNumber="210"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// So any constant equal or bitcastable to A is equal or bitcastable to B.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00211" /><CodeLine lineNumber="211"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// QED.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00212" /><CodeLine lineNumber="212"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00213" /><CodeLine lineNumber="213"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// In another words, for pointers and vectors, we ignore top-level type and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00214" /><CodeLine lineNumber="214"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// look at their particular properties (bit-width for vectors, and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00215" /><CodeLine lineNumber="215"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// address space for pointers).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00216" /><CodeLine lineNumber="216"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If these properties are equal - compare their contents.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00217" /><CodeLine lineNumber="217"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#aecc5ef45f49070634ddd53a04ed5548e">cmpConstants</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constant">Constant</a> &#42;L, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constant">Constant</a> &#42;R) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00218" /><CodeLine lineNumber="218"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00219" /><CodeLine lineNumber="219"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Compares two global values by number. Uses the GlobalNumbersState to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00220" /><CodeLine lineNumber="220"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// identify the same gobals across function calls.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00221" /><CodeLine lineNumber="221"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#ad251347b1feac30dc71e64f61b2ea195">cmpGlobalValues</a>(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvalue">GlobalValue</a> &#42;L, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvalue">GlobalValue</a> &#42;R) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00222" /><CodeLine lineNumber="222"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00223" /><CodeLine lineNumber="223"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Assign or look up previously assigned numbers for the two values, and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00224" /><CodeLine lineNumber="224"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// return whether the numbers are equal. Numbers are assigned in the order</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00225" /><CodeLine lineNumber="225"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// visited.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00226" /><CodeLine lineNumber="226"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Comparison order:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00227" /><CodeLine lineNumber="227"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 0: Value that is function itself is always greater then others.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00228" /><CodeLine lineNumber="228"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          If left and right values are references to their functions, then</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00229" /><CodeLine lineNumber="229"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          they are equal.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00230" /><CodeLine lineNumber="230"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 1: Constants are greater than non-constants.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00231" /><CodeLine lineNumber="231"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          If both left and right are constants, then the result of</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00232" /><CodeLine lineNumber="232"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          cmpConstants is used as cmpValues result.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00233" /><CodeLine lineNumber="233"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 2: InlineAsm instances are greater than others. If both left and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00234" /><CodeLine lineNumber="234"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          right are InlineAsm instances, InlineAsm&#42; pointers casted to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00235" /><CodeLine lineNumber="235"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          integers and compared as numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00236" /><CodeLine lineNumber="236"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stage 3: For all other cases we compare order we meet these values in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00237" /><CodeLine lineNumber="237"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          their functions. If right value was met first during scanning,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00238" /><CodeLine lineNumber="238"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          then left value is greater.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00239" /><CodeLine lineNumber="239"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          In another words, we compare serial numbers, for more details</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00240" /><CodeLine lineNumber="240"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///          see comments for sn&#95;mapL and sn&#95;mapR.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00241" /><CodeLine lineNumber="241"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#ac7b438ce165bdc9f0bff4c55f8c0f499">cmpValues</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42;L, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42;R) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00242" /><CodeLine lineNumber="242"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00243" /><CodeLine lineNumber="243"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Compare two Instructions for equivalence, similar to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00244" /><CodeLine lineNumber="244"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Instruction::isSameOperationAs.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00245" /><CodeLine lineNumber="245"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00246" /><CodeLine lineNumber="246"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stages are listed in &quot;most significant stage first&quot; order:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00247" /><CodeLine lineNumber="247"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// On each stage below, we do comparison between some left and right</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00248" /><CodeLine lineNumber="248"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// operation parts. If parts are non-equal, we assign parts comparison</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00249" /><CodeLine lineNumber="249"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// result to the operation comparison result and exit from method.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00250" /><CodeLine lineNumber="250"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Otherwise we proceed to the next stage.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00251" /><CodeLine lineNumber="251"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Stages:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00252" /><CodeLine lineNumber="252"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 Operations opcodes. Compared as numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00253" /><CodeLine lineNumber="253"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 Number of operands.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00254" /><CodeLine lineNumber="254"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 3 Operation types. Compared with cmpType method.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00255" /><CodeLine lineNumber="255"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 4 Compare operation subclass optional data as stream of bytes:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00256" /><CodeLine lineNumber="256"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// just convert it to integers and call cmpNumbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00257" /><CodeLine lineNumber="257"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 5 Compare in operation operand types with cmpType in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00258" /><CodeLine lineNumber="258"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// most significant operand first order.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00259" /><CodeLine lineNumber="259"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6 Last stage. Check operations for some specific attributes.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00260" /><CodeLine lineNumber="260"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// For example, for Load it would be:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00261" /><CodeLine lineNumber="261"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6.1.Load: volatile (as boolean flag)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00262" /><CodeLine lineNumber="262"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6.2.Load: alignment (as integer numbers)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00263" /><CodeLine lineNumber="263"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6.3.Load: ordering (as underlying enum class value)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00264" /><CodeLine lineNumber="264"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6.4.Load: synch-scope (as integer numbers)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00265" /><CodeLine lineNumber="265"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6.5.Load: range metadata (as integer ranges)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="266"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// On this stage its better to see the code, since its not more than 10-15</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="267"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// strings for particular instruction, and could change sometimes.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="268"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00269" /><CodeLine lineNumber="269"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Sets \\p needToCmpOperands to true if the operands of the instructions</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="270"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// still must be compared afterwards. In this case it&#39;s already guaranteed</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="271"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// that both instructions have the same number of operands.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00272" /><CodeLine lineNumber="272"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#aa359aa2850f74fbc9dbdb4650c13f4cf">cmpOperations</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42;L, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42;R,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00273" /><CodeLine lineNumber="273"><Highlight kind="normal">                    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">bool</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> &amp;needToCmpOperands) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00274" /><CodeLine lineNumber="274"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00275" /><CodeLine lineNumber="275"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// cmpType - compares two types,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="276"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// defines total ordering among the types set.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="277"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="278"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Return values:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="279"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 0 if types are equal,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="280"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// -1 if Left is less than Right,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="281"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 if Left is greater than Right.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="282"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="283"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Description:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="284"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Comparison is broken onto stages. Like in lexicographical comparison</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="285"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// stage coming first has higher priority.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00286" /><CodeLine lineNumber="286"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// On each explanation stage keep in mind total ordering properties.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00287" /><CodeLine lineNumber="287"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00288" /><CodeLine lineNumber="288"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 0 Before comparison we coerce pointer types of 0 address space to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00289" /><CodeLine lineNumber="289"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// integer.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00290" /><CodeLine lineNumber="290"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// We also don&#39;t bother with same type at left and right, so</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00291" /><CodeLine lineNumber="291"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// just return 0 in this case.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00292" /><CodeLine lineNumber="292"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00293" /><CodeLine lineNumber="293"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 If types are of different kind (different type IDs).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00294" /><CodeLine lineNumber="294"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///    Return result of type IDs comparison, treating them as numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00295" /><CodeLine lineNumber="295"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 If types are integers, check that they have the same width. If they</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00296" /><CodeLine lineNumber="296"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// are vectors, check that they have the same count and subtype.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00297" /><CodeLine lineNumber="297"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 3 Types have the same ID, so check whether they are one of:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00298" /><CodeLine lineNumber="298"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; Void</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00299" /><CodeLine lineNumber="299"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; Float</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00300" /><CodeLine lineNumber="300"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; Double</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00301" /><CodeLine lineNumber="301"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; X86&#95;FP80</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00302" /><CodeLine lineNumber="302"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; FP128</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00303" /><CodeLine lineNumber="303"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; PPC&#95;FP128</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00304" /><CodeLine lineNumber="304"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; Label</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00305" /><CodeLine lineNumber="305"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#42; Metadata</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00306" /><CodeLine lineNumber="306"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// We can treat these types as equal whenever their IDs are same.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00307" /><CodeLine lineNumber="307"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 4 If Left and Right are pointers, return result of address space</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00308" /><CodeLine lineNumber="308"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// comparison (numbers comparison). We can treat pointer types of same</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00309" /><CodeLine lineNumber="309"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// address space as equal.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00310" /><CodeLine lineNumber="310"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 5 If types are complex.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00311" /><CodeLine lineNumber="311"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Then both Left and Right are to be expanded and their element types will</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00312" /><CodeLine lineNumber="312"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// be checked with the same way. If we get Res != 0 on some stage, return it.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00313" /><CodeLine lineNumber="313"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Otherwise return 0</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00314" /><CodeLine lineNumber="314"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 6 For all other cases put llvm&#95;unreachable.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00315" /><CodeLine lineNumber="315"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#a96167048c547bb562d69720cee2a48a6">cmpTypes</a>(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42;TyL, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42;TyR) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00316" /><CodeLine lineNumber="316"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00318" /><CodeLine lineNumber="318"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#abec80b03038382f41e2f3217db10d729">cmpAligns</a>(<a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/align">Align</a> L, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/align">Align</a> R) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00323" /><CodeLine lineNumber="323"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00324" /><CodeLine lineNumber="324"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The two functions undergoing comparison.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00325" /><CodeLine lineNumber="325" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#a6ab58e4d2fb258a0d2c839fbfdae9024"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &#42;<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#a6ab58e4d2fb258a0d2c839fbfdae9024">FnL</a>, &#42;<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functioncomparator/#a2fec2baea95adaabe3bec634298422db">FnR</a>;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00335" /><CodeLine lineNumber="335"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00336" /><CodeLine lineNumber="336"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Compare two GEPs for equivalent pointer arithmetic.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00337" /><CodeLine lineNumber="337"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Parts to be compared for each comparison stage,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00338" /><CodeLine lineNumber="338"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// most significant stage first:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00339" /><CodeLine lineNumber="339"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 Address space. As numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00340" /><CodeLine lineNumber="340"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 Constant offset, (using GEPOperator::accumulateConstantOffset method).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00341" /><CodeLine lineNumber="341"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 3 Pointer operand type (using cmpType method).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00342" /><CodeLine lineNumber="342"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 4 Number of operands.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00343" /><CodeLine lineNumber="343"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 5 Compare operands, using cmpValues method.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00344" /><CodeLine lineNumber="344"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> cmpGEPs(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/gepoperator">GEPOperator</a> &#42;GEPL, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/gepoperator">GEPOperator</a> &#42;GEPR) </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00345" /><CodeLine lineNumber="345"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">int</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> cmpGEPs(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/getelementptrinst">GetElementPtrInst</a> &#42;GEPL,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00346" /><CodeLine lineNumber="346"><Highlight kind="normal">              </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/getelementptrinst">GetElementPtrInst</a> &#42;GEPR)</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword"> const </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">&#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00347" /><CodeLine lineNumber="347"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordflow">return</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> cmpGEPs(<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#ac4fc845f5ed92de63cd4474f128f5fc5">cast&lt;GEPOperator&gt;</a>(GEPL), <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#ac4fc845f5ed92de63cd4474f128f5fc5">cast&lt;GEPOperator&gt;</a>(GEPR));</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00348" /><CodeLine lineNumber="348"><Highlight kind="normal">  &#125;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00349" /><CodeLine lineNumber="349"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00350" /><CodeLine lineNumber="350"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Assign serial numbers to values from left function, and values from</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00351" /><CodeLine lineNumber="351"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// right function.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00352" /><CodeLine lineNumber="352"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Explanation:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00353" /><CodeLine lineNumber="353"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Being comparing functions we need to compare values we meet at left and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00354" /><CodeLine lineNumber="354"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// right sides.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00355" /><CodeLine lineNumber="355"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Its easy to sort things out for external values. It just should be</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00356" /><CodeLine lineNumber="356"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// the same value at left and right.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00357" /><CodeLine lineNumber="357"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// But for local values (those were introduced inside function body)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00358" /><CodeLine lineNumber="358"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// we have to ensure they were introduced at exactly the same place,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00359" /><CodeLine lineNumber="359"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// and plays the same role.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00360" /><CodeLine lineNumber="360"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Let&#39;s assign serial number to each value when we meet it first time.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00361" /><CodeLine lineNumber="361"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Values that were met at same place will be with same serial numbers.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00362" /><CodeLine lineNumber="362"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// In this case it would be good to explain few points about values assigned</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00363" /><CodeLine lineNumber="363"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// to BBs and other ways of implementation (see below).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00364" /><CodeLine lineNumber="364"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00365" /><CodeLine lineNumber="365"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 1 Safety of BB reordering.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00366" /><CodeLine lineNumber="366"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// It&#39;s safe to change the order of BasicBlocks in function.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00367" /><CodeLine lineNumber="367"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Relationship with other functions and serial numbering will not be</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00368" /><CodeLine lineNumber="368"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// changed in this case.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00369" /><CodeLine lineNumber="369"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// As follows from FunctionComparator::compare(), we do CFG walk: we start</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00370" /><CodeLine lineNumber="370"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// from the entry, and then take each terminator. So it doesn&#39;t matter how in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00371" /><CodeLine lineNumber="371"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// fact BBs are ordered in function. And since cmpValues are called during</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00372" /><CodeLine lineNumber="372"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// this walk, the numbering depends only on how BBs located inside the CFG.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00373" /><CodeLine lineNumber="373"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// So the answer is - yes. We will get the same numbering.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00374" /><CodeLine lineNumber="374"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00375" /><CodeLine lineNumber="375"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// 2 Impossibility to use dominance properties of values.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00376" /><CodeLine lineNumber="376"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If we compare two instruction operands: first is usage of local</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00377" /><CodeLine lineNumber="377"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// variable AL from function FL, and second is usage of local variable AR</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00378" /><CodeLine lineNumber="378"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// from FR, we could compare their origins and check whether they are</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00379" /><CodeLine lineNumber="379"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// defined at the same place.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00380" /><CodeLine lineNumber="380"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// But, we are still not able to compare operands of PHI nodes, since those</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00381" /><CodeLine lineNumber="381"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// could be operands from further BBs we didn&#39;t scan yet.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00382" /><CodeLine lineNumber="382"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// So it&#39;s impossible to use dominance properties in general.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00383" /><CodeLine lineNumber="383"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">mutable</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/densemap">DenseMap&lt;const Value&#42;, int&gt;</a> sn&#95;mapL, sn&#95;mapR;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00384" /><CodeLine lineNumber="384"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00385" /><CodeLine lineNumber="385"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The global state we will use</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00386" /><CodeLine lineNumber="386"><Highlight kind="normal">  <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalnumberstate">GlobalNumberState</a>&#42; GlobalNumbers;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00387" /><CodeLine lineNumber="387"><Highlight kind="normal">&#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00388" /><CodeLine lineNumber="388"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00389" /><CodeLine lineNumber="389"><Highlight kind="normal">&#125; </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// end namespace llvm</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00390" /><CodeLine lineNumber="390"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00391" /><CodeLine lineNumber="391"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="preprocessor">#endif </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LLVM&#95;TRANSFORMS&#95;UTILS&#95;FUNCTIONCOMPARATOR&#95;H</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
